The Ottomans had a weird system. Why would you have your sons scatter to the provinces to then raise political factions in those provinces? That's the easiest way to foment civil wars between competing brothers once the father sultan died, with their factions egging them on. The better way was the Chinese way--DON'T allow your sons to scatter to the provinces, keep them under tight control in one court, have the oldest son ascend the throne, and keep most government power in the hands of scholar-bureaucrats who attain their positions through examinations and other meritocratic mechanisms.

Kudos to you guys on covering Eastern Europe, as opposed to a widespread distorted view that the European history is only the history of its Western part.
However, I should point out that mixing in the Ottoman and the Russian empires into it is confusing to a viewer. It's like adding a Brittish and a Dutch history into the history of, well, Asia. Just because at some point of time those civilizations captured some parts of it, doesn't mean they are representative of those parts.
It would probably be more appropriate to present Eastern Europe through the prism of what is called today Jagiellonian kingdoms, i.e. kingdoms ruled at some point of time by the Jagiellonian dynasty: Kingdom of Poland, Kingdom of Hungary (and Croatia), Kingdom of Bohemia, and the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, as well as their various dependencies. There were many more similarities between those - like freedoms of religion, democratic elements, causes of their internal conflicts and decline, etc.
If you look at Eastern Europe as a big stretch between Sweeden and Turks, it looks too confusing.
If you look at Eastern Europe as a complex gentrified organism that was trying to withstand the pressure from all four sides, occasionally coming together from the fields of Grunwald to Varna to Breadfield, etc., while also producing intellectual responses from religious, like Hussites and Unitarians, to legal like Serbian Zakonnik, Hungarian Tripartitum, Lithuanian Statutes, and Ukrainian Consitution of Pylyp Orlyk - then it starts to look a bit more organized.

Mehmed II*

I guess you could have mentioned the Hetman state, which existed on Ukrainian territory from the mid-17th century up to the late 18th century (these dates partially overlapped the Russian history bit you covered). Also, there were many distinct groups of Cossacks: there were Zaporizhian cossacks in Ukraine, and Don, Terek, Kuban and Yaik cossacks in Russia. In the conflict between Russia and Poland, Zaporizhian cossacks were the one who took part, and they were employed by both sides. There was also an institution of Registered Cossacks, which were formally acknowledged by the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth (and thus were acting not as mercenaries, but more as an actual part of their military). The Hetman State, in fact, was a separate entity from the Zaporizhian cossacks, and its military rulers (Hetmans) would at times align towards the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, and at other times -- towards Russia (which means certain Hetmans were pro-Polish, and others were pro-Russian). In fact, in the latter days of its existence, the Hetman State split into the Left-Bank and Right-Bank parts, with regards to the river Dnipro. The left-bank (eastern) part was pro-Russian, and the right-bank (western) part was pro-Polish (obviously there were nuances on the "pro-" part, some Hetmans showed a lot more support to the corresponding countries than others, but the idea is that the Hetman State was kind of a fledgling entity with a decent army, but lacking the political power (and thus requiring strong allies). Ultimately, the last remnants of the Hetman State were removed by Catherine II in 1764.

An interesting thing about cossacks, which nobody mentions, is that many of them (if not most of them) were either not slavic or not christian. Their name comes from a turkic word, they used to wear turkic attires (until the Caucasian War, at which point they started wearing caucasian attires), use turkic weapons, etc. Also, if you look at the geography, they mainly lived in Ukraine, which was for the majority of history inhabited by turkic muslims, as well as being that part of Russian Empire where they sent all the jewish people (cause they weren't allowed to live in Russia proper). The cossack land was famous for embracing all the criminals, that were escaping persecution in Russia proper, and a lot of them were escaping religious and ethnic persecution. Also, yeah, the word "Kazakh", that denotes the people of Kazakhstan, is the exact same word as Cossack. In 20th century the Soviets decided to change "к" into "х" for the kazakhs, just to distinguish between them. So, it wouldn't be incorrect to call both of them "Kazaks" like portrayed in the video.

As someone from south eastern Europe I think that it is important to understand that the ottoman devshirme or the blood tax wasn't just drafting or levying. The age that people were taken was often 8-10. A lot of the times you had people forcibly maim their children to avoid being ripped away from their family while other families did give away their sons typically because they were already poor and opportunities were limited. After being taken these kids often didn't get to see their families until they rose up high enough in the ranks to win some form of autonomy.

This is a sore subject in the region and is not well known in many western European countries or in america and I think it is important that anyone that is trying to understand this from the outside know that the issue is pretty complex.

Regarding the Ottoman kidnapping of children:
-The system was called devshirme, and was in place from the late 14th through to mid 17th century.
-Christian boys were taken, converted and then divided to different institutions, which were called Palace, Scribes, Religious and Military, the last one producing the Janissary soldiers. The Palace was were the smartest boys were sent to become high officials, some eventually becoming viziers.
-Jews, Muslims, sons of craftsmen, urban populations, only sons and boys with bodily defects were exempt from the devshirme.
-Families of the boys reacted in different ways: some went as far as mutilating their sons to exempt them, others would bribe officials to pick their sons for a life of wealth. Converting to Islam was also a way of escaping.
-Though the Janissaries were slaves, they were paid a regular salary and a pension after service.
-Eventually, the privileges enjoyed by the Janissary class led to free Muslims demanding access to their ranks. Due to manpower pressures, this and the inclusion of children of janissaries were eventually allowed, leading to the decline of the devshirme. The boy harvests became rare events after the reign of Suleyman the Magnificent and number of boys taken shrunk as other recruitment methods prevailed.
-By the time the devshirme was formally abolished in 1703 it had been defunct for decades.
Just wanted to inject some nuance into the discussion. Also, I don't see how the devshirme existing would counter the fact that the Ottoman Empire was religiously more tolerant than other European states.

Important to note that the "liberalism" of Poland-Lithuania is viewed as the cause for its decline. The concept of "Golden Liberty" does sound a lot like what the American liberal revolutionaries espoused, except for one major difference. All those freedoms, the Sejm (the parliament) only applied to the nobility. It wasn't a centralized republic, it was more like noble anarchy. While the countries around us centralized and the rulers raised gigantic armies, the Rzeczpospolita regressed - any king seeking to reform the state faced fierced and sometimes armed opposition from the nobles. The noble parliament was prone to foreign manipulation and so, what was once the largest European state was nothing more than a buffer state for the new great powers, in the sphere of influence of Russia.

Learning about the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth actually solidified/shaped a lot of my political views: that religious tolerance is good and a society where various faiths are able to openly and peacefully exist side-by-side is to be desired, that scientific study should be encouraged by the government, and that multiculturalism is a good thing - and other views that I developed from learning about the Commonwealth's decline, like "why would you ever have something like liberum veto?" or "all people should have the same rights regardless of class" or "ethnic minorities within a country should have a right to self-determination". It even defined how I understand what being Polish MEANS... which it looks like most of my country disagrees with right now, but I'm still hopeful

I think it’s important to mention a bit more about the murder of Jews by the Cossacks. The Cossacks are still considered an absolutely terrifying force to Ashkenazi Jews. During those skirmishes with what we would now call parts of the Ukraine, the Polish Lithuanian Commonwealth, despite being a “safe haven” for Jews (which let’s be honest is all relative) experienced a genocide against its Jewish population beginning in 1648 and lasting until the late 1650s which was carried out by Hetman Khmelnytsky his Cossack followers, as well as many locals. Tens of thousands of Jews were murdered, potentially over 100,000 people. Up until the Holocaust, 1648 was considered one of the worst churbanim (destructions) in Jewish history.

Wowowowowow!!! It was Mehmed the Second! Mehmet the First was the 5th sultan, managed to re conquer the lost Anatolian territories after Bayezid the First entered a disasterous war with Timurleng!


That time of disorder(Literally called the Disorder Era) actually shaped Ottoman Empire's structure a lot.

When the turkmen tribes changed sides on the battlefield, to regain their lost liberties when Ottomans raise to power after the Seljuks, and Serbian reinforcements standing their ground until the very end to keep their word to their new ally muslims(!), Ottomans saw one thing clear.


1) Christians can be reliable on the battlefield and they're not a bunch of wusses, given the right motivations, christian, non turkic or non muslim soldiers are fierce and devoted enough to die to the very end.
2) Turkmens are not reliable, they were still very nomadic at the time, Seljuk Empire did not have the centralised government, they were strictly tolerant and did not believe in a fully centralised government, and unlike Ottomans, Seljuks spent a lot of money and effort for the peoples of Anatolia, both christians(About %40 of the land was christian) and turkic tribes.


4th Sultan Bayezid the Fourth, tried to enforce all nomadic tribes to rule as his men, by his word, and his own law. Which, for the nomads, is not something that's lovely, because it would mean they can be roughshouldered by any ruler, be neglected and their grasslands would be taken away.


When Timurleng and Bayezid had a huge dispute by letters, not dissimilar to a YouTube argument, and the war of Ankara happened, that whole system you talked in here had been solidified.


Devşirmes were starting to be more favoured in the court. Because Ottomans wanted their high officials depending on the sultan, not family or wealth.

Marrying slowly became unpopular, because a, in time there were not enough factions to make marrige contracts, Selim the First destroyed most of them. And b, concubines are disposable. If anything happened to any of them, nobody cared too much.


So in about 17th century, %90 of Ottoman court were christian converts, turks were neglected in inner Anatolia, Ottomans deliberatly did not make any attempts to increase the life standards of those people, and the government thrived, and managed to live on through a lot of disasters and debacles that would've broken any other state.


Of course, modernisation of the world and nationalism, was something that even Ottoman practicality can't cope with.

We're talking about a state, that formed a constitution in a few days, just by looking at the European constitutions and nit picking parts of it that would be sufficient to make a good guideline for the state and the people.

Facts you may find interesting about Ivan the IV:
1. During his childhood Ivan witnessed a murder of some family members during power struggle between noble clans. As a result he gradually developed psycologic conditions which worsened with age.
2. Ivan was the longest-ruling head of Russia: more than 62 years!
3. Ivan was deeply in love with his first wife. It was said she was the only one who could calm his anger. When she died, he became notably paranoid.
4. Ivan invented the first secret service in Russia: "oprichnina". It worked very much like KGB of its time. A word "oprichnik" is still used as a swear-word for state terror.
5. Ivan won several wars against foreign states but also burned down some Russian cities as he thought they were too independent.
6. In his old age he often prayed to God for forgiveness of his sins. He even established a pension for the families of his executed political rivals.
